text: it is the most bizarre ritual the
coffins are ready the company these
Koreans work for has brought its
employees together to contemplate the
meaning of life and death
eyes are moist they've just written
final letters to their loved ones then
at the grim climax of what is a
simulated mass funeral they get into the
caskets which are knocked shut inside
they're confined in darkness and
contemplation for ten minutes and then
they see the light he and Hugh Rowland
tell me when I realized that made lots
of mistakes I hope to be more passionate
in all the work I do and spend more time
with my family the aim of this employee
ritual is to instill a love of life and
to teach workers to appreciate the good
things rather than seeing the downside
the president of the company told me he
wants to strengthen the sense of
corporate togetherness tygon he says our
company's always encouraged employees to
change their old ways of thinking but it
was hard to bring about any real
difference I thought going inside a
coffin would be such a shock that it
would completely reset their minds for a
fresh start in attitudes and there is
another office ritual forced laughter
every morning at work the supervisor
overseas employees all laughing together
as one the workers say they value the
coffin ritual and the laughter but it's
hard to know how enthusiastic they
really are
Korean companies devise all kinds of
bonding exercises virtually from cradle
to grave there's competition
it makes for a strong economy whether it
also makes for harmony and happiness is
not so clear Stephen Evans BBC News so
